items.description: A protein made by the liver. High amounts of C-reactive protein may indicate that arteries are clogged (atherosclerosis).

items.name: creatine kinase
items.description: An enzyme that leaks into the bloodstream in high amounts if a muscle is damaged. Can be used to detect heart attack or muscle damage from other diseases.

items.name: creatinine
items.description: A waste product created by muscle metabolism. Doctors sometimes test creatinine levels to examine kidney function.

items.name: creatinine test
items.description: A blood or urine test that helps doctors determine if the kidneys are working properly.

items.name: crepitus
items.description: Grating, grinding, or popping sound or feeling made when a joint is moved.

items.name: Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease
items.description: A rare, untreatable, rapid form of dementia that is fatal.

items.name: Crohn's disease
items.description: A chronic disease that causes swelling of the digestive tract, pain, and diarrhea.

items.name: crown
items.description: The part of the tooth that is visible above the gum line. Also a restoration that covers the crown of the tooth.

items.name: cryotherapy
items.description: Use of extreme cold to freeze and destroy diseased tissue.

items.name: CRP
items.description: Abbreviation for C-reactive protein, a protein made by the liver. High amounts of C-reactive protein may indicate that arteries are clogged (atherosclerosis).

items.name: crystalline lens
items.description: Part of the eye that changes shape so that the eye can focus on objects at different distances.

items.name: CT
items.description: Computerized x-rays that provide detailed views of the body and brain. Also known as a computed tomography (CT) scan.

items.name: CT angiography
items.description: Use of a CT scan and an injectable dye to show arteries and blood vessels in detail.

items.name: cubital tunnel syndrome
items.description: The pinching of a nerve at the elbow, causing numbness in the pinkie and ring fingers and part of the hand.

items.name: cupping
items.description: An indentation in the optic disc that grows abnormally large with glaucoma.

items.name: curettage
items.description: Using a spoon-shaped instrument to remove diseased tissue or sample tissue.

items.name: Cushing's syndrome
items.description: A disorder caused by high levels of the stress-hormone cortisol resulting in damage to the body, including abdominal obesity, rounded red face, and other symptoms.

items.name: cuticle
items.description: The outermost, single-cell layer of the hair shaft.

items.name: cyanosis
items.description: A condition in which skin turns blue due to a lack of oxygen in the blood, often because of heart failure or lung disease.

items.name: cyclic guanosine monophosphate
items.description: A chemical in the body that widens blood vessels in the penis. This increases blood flow to the penis, causing an erection.

items.name: cyclic hormone therapy
items.description: Use of estrogen and progestogen for 10–14 days of the month to relieve symptoms of menopause.

items.name: cyclooxygenase
items.description: An enzyme that helps blood cells known as platelets stick to each other, a key step in the formation of a blood clot.

items.name: cyst
items.description: An abnormal growth in the body that is noncancerous.

items.name: cystoid macular edema
items.description: An eye condition in which the retina (the macula) becomes swollen with fluid.

items.name: cytokines
items.description: Proteins in the body that act as messengers between immune system cells.

items.name: cytotoxic alopecia
items.description: Drug-induced hair loss that occurs some weeks after the start of chemotherapy; hair grows back after cessation of treatment.

items.name: D2 receptor
items.description: A type of dopamine receptor (see neurotransmitter receptors) that seems to be particularly important in addiction.

items.name: daidzein
items.description: A substance found in soybeans.

items.name: daily value
items.description: A guide to the amount of nutrients in a given food; Daily values are given in percentages based on a 2,000-calorie-per-day diet.

items.name: dandruff
items.description: A mild and common condition that is characterized by an itchy, flaky scalp and that may extend to the ears, face, and chest. Also known as seborrheic dermatitis.

items.name: de Quervain’s tendonitis
items.description: Painful swelling of the tendons at the wrist that move the thumb.

items.name: debility
items.description: Weakness or a loss of physical strength.

items.name: decibel
items.description: A unit of measurement for the loudness of a sound. The highest decibels indicate the loudest sounds.

items.name: declarative memory
items.description: Memory for facts or events (episodic memory); also called explicit memory.

items.name: decoction
items.description: An herbal product or tea made by boiling a plant in water.

items.name: decongestant
items.description: Type of medication used to relieve nasal congestion.

items.name: deep sleep
items.description: Stage of sleep where the brain is less responsive to outside stimuli.

items.name: deep venous thrombosis
items.description: A dangerous condition in which blood clots form in veins deep in the body, usually the legs. They may break off and block blood flow in the lungs, seriously damaging organs or causing death.

items.name: defenses
items.description: Coping strategies a person adopts to make it easier to operate in the world.

items.name: defibrillation
items.description: The delivery of an electric shock to the heart to stop an abnormal rhythm and restore a normal heartbeat.

items.name: defibrillator
items.description: A device that delivers an electric shock to the heart to restore normal rhythm. Used to treat cardiac arrest and other dangerous heart rhythm problems.

items.name: degenerative disease
items.description: Any disease in which the organs or tissues in the body are damaged progressively over time.

items.name: degenerative disk disease
items.description: Normal, and sometimes painful, deteriorations in the disks of the spine that occur with age.

items.name: degenerative joint disease
items.description: Arthritis that occurs when the cartilage in joints breaks down over time; also called osteoarthritis.

items.name: degenerative spondylolisthesis
items.description: Arthritis of the spine that worsens over time; often caused by aging.

items.name: delayed sleep phase syndrome
items.description: A pattern of falling asleep and waking up later than wanted that tends to worsen progressively over time.

items.name: delirium
items.description: Sudden, severe confusion that occurs because of a mental or physical illness.

items.name: delta waves
items.description: Slow brain activity that occurs when a person is in deep sleep.

items.name: delusion
items.description: A false or irrational belief held by a person despite evidence to the contrary.

items.name: dementia
items.description: A loss of brain function that worsens over time and affects memory, thinking, behavior, and language.

items.name: dementia pugilistica
items.description: Loss of brain function, common among former boxers, caused by repeated blows to the head.

items.name: demineralization
items.description: The process by which bacteria destroy tooth enamel.

items.name: demulcent
items.description: A substance that soothes irritated tissues and mucous membranes.

items.name: dendrites
items.description: The parts of a nerve cell that receive signals from other nerve cells.

items.name: dendritic cells
items.description: Spidery-looking immune system cells that help protect the body from harmful substances.

items.name: denial
items.description: A defense mechanism characterized by the inability to recognize or admit that addiction is the cause of problems, rather than a solution or mere byproduct. Denial can also refer to the refusal to accept an upsetting reality, such as a serious illness or death or the feelings that follow either.

items.name: dental implant
items.description: A metal post inserted into the alveolar bone to support an artificial tooth or other prosthesis.

items.name: dentin
items.description: The layer of hardened tooth tissue under the enamel and around the pulp.

items.name: deoxyribonucleic acid
items.description: The substance found in the nucleus of cells that contains the genetic instructions for that living organism.

items.name: dermal papilla
items.description: A structure situated at the base of the hair follicle that contains nerves and blood vessels that fuel the cellular processes of the developing hair shaft.

items.name: dermatomyositis
items.description: A rare disease in which the muscles become weak and stiff and a skin rash appears.

items.name: dermis
items.description: The middle layer of skin that contains most of the skin’s structures, like collagen, nerves, glands, and hair follicles.

items.name: desiccated thyroid
items.description: An extract made of dried animal thyroid glands.

items.name: detoxification
items.description: The process of removing harmful, or toxic, substances from a person’s body.

items.name: detrusor instability
items.description: The sudden, strong need to urinate due to spasms in bladder muscles. Also called urge incontinence.

items.name: detrusor muscle
items.description: The layer of muscle in the bladder wall that squeezes urine out of the bladder.

items.name: detumescence
items.description: The softening of an erection.

items.name: diabetes
items.description: A disease in which the body does not properly produce or use insulin, resulting in abnormally high levels of sugar (glucose) in the blood.

items.name: diabetic ketoacidosis
items.description: A complication of diabetes in which substances called ketones build up in the blood to dangerously high levels.

items.name: diabetic retinopathy
items.description: A complication of diabetes that occurs when the small blood vessels in the retina are damaged. It can impair vision or even lead to blindness.

items.name: diaphragm
items.description: The dome-shaped sheet of muscle at the base of the lungs that helps move air in and out of the lungs.

items.name: diastole
items.description: The relaxation phase of the normal heart cycle.

items.name: diastolic blood pressure
items.description: The bottom number of a blood pressure reading, such as 134/78. It represents the pressure in the arteries when the heart relaxes between beats.

items.name: diastolic heart failure
items.description: The inability of the heart to relax properly between beats (diastole), making it difficult for the ventricles to fill completely with blood from the atria. This can occur when the heart muscle bulks up due to overwork or other causes or when the heart muscle stiffens and loses it flexibility.

items.name: diathermy
items.description: Use of high-frequency electric currents to heat deep muscle and joint tissue as a form of physical therapy.

items.name: dietary fiber
items.description: The part of plant foods the body can’t digest or absorb. Also called roughage.

items.name: dietary reference intakes
items.description: The recommended amount of vitamins and minerals individuals should consume per day.

items.name: dietary supplements
items.description: Vitamins, minerals, herbs, and other substances taken in hopes of improving health.

items.name: digestive tract
items.description: The series of hollow organs, including the mouth, esophagus, stomach, small intestine, large intestine (colon), rectum, and anus, which break down and digest food and expel waste.

items.name: digit
items.description: A finger or toe.

items.name: digital rectal examination
items.description: An exam in which a doctor inserts a lubricated, gloved finger into the rectum to check for abnormalities.

items.name: digitalis
items.description: A drug that increases the strength of heart muscle contractions.

items.name: dihydrotestosterone
items.description: A form of the hormone testosterone that spurs the prostate gland to enlarge (benign prostatic hyperplasia).

items.name: dilate
items.description: To widen or enlarge.

items.name: direct transmission
items.description: The immediate transfer of an infectious agent from a reservoir to a susceptible host by direct contact or droplet spread.

items.name: discoid lupus erythematosus
items.description: A rare form of lupus that causes a rash or scarring of skin.

items.name: disk
items.description: One of the small, shock-absorbing cushions found between the bones that make up the spinal column (vertebrae).

items.name: diskectomy
items.description: The surgical removal of part of a disk (a small, shock absorbing cushion located between the bones of the spinal column).

items.name: diskitis
items.description: Swelling of one or more of the pillow-like disks located between the bones of the spinal column.

items.name: dislocation
items.description: The movement of a bone from its normal position.

items.name: dithiolethione
items.description: A substance found in cruciferous vegetables, like cabbage, Brussels sprouts, and broccoli, which may play a role in cancer prevention.

items.name: diuretic
items.description: A drug that eases the heart's workload and decreases the buildup of fluid in the lungs and other parts of the body by promoting the excretion of water and salts. Diuretics (also called water pills) are used to treat high blood pressure, heart failure, and some congenital heart defects.

items.name: diverticulitis
items.description: The bulging out of small pouches or sacs of tissue from the colon wall.

items.name: diverticulum
items.description: A small pouch or sac of tissue that bulges out of the colon wall. The plural form is diverticula.

items.name: d-limonene
items.description: A substance found in citrus fruits.

items.name: DNA
items.description: An abbreviation for deoxyribonucleic acid, the substance in cells that contains the genetic instructions that direct their function.

items.name: DNR
items.description: Commonly used abbreviation for do-not-resuscitate order, a legal document that tells health professionals not to revive a person if his or her heart or breathing stops.

items.name: dominant
items.description: When the genetic trait carried by one allele of a gene pair eclipses the trait carried by another; for example, when a gene carries alleles for two different eye colors, the dominant eye color gene determines the person’s eye color.do-not-resuscitate order : A legal document that tells health professionals not to revive a person if his or her heart or breathing stops. Commonly referred to as a DNR.

items.name: dopamine
items.description: A chemical messenger (neurotransmitter) that affects movement and thought processes.

items.name: Doppler ultrasound
items.description: A test that uses sound waves to measure how fast blood is flowing through blood vessels.

items.name: dorsal
items.description: Near the back of the body or an organ.

items.name: dorsal kyphosis
items.description: A rounded or curved back caused by spinal fractures from osteoporosis. Commonly called dowager’s hump.

items.name: double blind
items.description: A medical study in which the researchers and participants don’t know which group is receiving the medication or treatment being studied and which is getting a placebo (fake, inactive version of the medication).

items.name: double-contrast barium enema
items.description: An x-ray test done to check for colon cancer or other bowel diseases.

items.name: dowager's hump
items.description: A rounded or curved back (resembling a hump) caused by spinal fractures from osteoporosis.

items.name: doxazosin
items.description: Medication used to treat high blood pressure or an enlarged prostate gland.

items.name: Dressler's syndrome
items.description: Inflammation of the sac surrounding the heart (pericardium).

items.name: DRI
items.description: Abbreviation for dietary reference intake, the recommended amount of vitamins and minerals individuals should consume per day.

items.name: drusen
items.description: Tiny yellow deposits in the retina of the eye.

items.name: dry eye
items.description: Stinging, burning, or irritation that occurs when the eye doesn’t produce enough moisture.

items.name: dry-powder inhaler
items.description: A small device that helps a person breathe in dry medication so it reaches the lungs.

items.name: dual energy x-ray absorptiometry
items.description: An x-ray test used to measure bone density and check for osteoporosis.

items.name: dual-photon absorptiometry
items.description: A test to measure bone density, usually in the spine or the hip.

items.name: duct
items.description: A tube or vessel in the body which carries the secretion of a gland; Secretion examples are tears, breast milk, etc.

items.name: duodenitis
items.description: Inflammation of the duodenum, which is the upper part of the small intestine.

items.name: duodenum
items.description: The upper part of the small intestine.

items.name: duplex Doppler ultrasound scanning
items.description: A tool that uses sound waves to reveal blood flow problems.

items.name: Dupuytren’s disease
items.description: A condition that deforms the hand, causing fingers to curl toward the palm.

items.name: dura mater
items.description: A thin protective membrane covering the brain and spinal cord.

items.name: durable power of attorney
items.description: A legal document in which an individual appoints another person to make medical, financial, or other decisions when the individual becomes unable to make those decisions.

items.name: dysarthria
items.description: A speech disability caused by an injury to the brain centers controlling the face, mouth, neck, or throat. People with dysarthria may be able to understand speech and form the right words in their mind but cannot articulate them.

items.name: dyspareunia
items.description: Painful sexual intercourse.

items.name: dyspepsia
items.description: Pain or discomfort in the upper abdomen; upset stomach or indigestion.

items.name: dysphagia
items.description: Difficulty chewing and swallowing food. Dysphagia is extremely common after a stroke.

items.name: dysplasia
items.description: Abnormal changes in cells of a tissue. The cells aren’t cancerous, but they can sometimes progress to cancer.

items.name: dyspnea
items.description: Difficulty breathing or shortness of breath.

items.name: dystonia
items.description: A disorder in which muscles twitch, causing uncontrollable twisting movements.

items.name: ear canal
items.description: A tube leading from the eardrum to the outer ear.

items.name: eardrum
items.description: A thin membrane separating the ear canal and middle ear.

items.name: earwax
items.description: A substance that lubricates the inner ear and helps protect it from dirt, damage, and infections.

items.name: EBCT
items.description: Abbreviation for electron-beam computed tomography, a high-speed imaging technology use to evaluate the heart and measure calcium deposits in arteries.

items.name: eccentric action
items.description: When muscles move joints by lengthening. Also known as cerumen.

items.name: ECG
items.description: An abbreviation for electrocardiogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.

items.name: echocardiography
items.description: A diagnostic tool that uses high-frequency sound waves (ultrasound) to make images of the heart's size, structure and motion.

items.name: eclampsia
items.description: A serious condition related to high blood pressure that can threaten the life of a pregnant woman and her fetus.

items.name: ectopic pregnancy
items.description: Pregnancy in which a fertilized egg implants in an abnormal location outside the uterus, usually in the fallopian tubes. Ending the pregnancy is necessary.

items.name: ectropion
items.description: When an eyelid, usually the lower one, flips outward so that the inner surface is exposed.

items.name: eczema
items.description: A condition in which areas of the skin are dry, itchy, red, and cracked. Also known as atopic dermatitis.

items.name: ED
items.description: Commonly used abbreviation for erectile dysfunction, the inability to get or maintain an erection sufficient for intercourse.

items.name: edema
items.description: Swelling caused by abnormal accumulation of fluid in tissues.

items.name: EEG
items.description: Abbreviation for electroencephalogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the brain and detects problems.

items.name: effusion
items.description: An abnormal buildup of fluid in a joint or tissue.

items.name: eighth cranial nerve
items.description: A nerve responsible transmitting sound and information about balance to the brain. Also called the auditory nerve.

items.name: ejaculation
items.description: A sudden discharge of a fluid from a duct; often used to describe the expulsion of seminal fluid from the urethra of the penis during orgasm.

items.name: ejection fraction
items.description: The percent of blood pumped out of the left ventricle with each heartbeat. A normal ejection fraction is in the range of 55% to 70%.

items.name: EKG
items.description: An abbreviation for electrocardiogram, a test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.

items.name: elastin
items.description: A flexible, stretchy protein found in skin and connective tissue.

items.name: electrocardiogram
items.description: A test that measures the electrical activity of the heart and detects heart problems.

items.name: electroencephalogram
items.description: A test that measures the electrical activity of the brain and detects problems.

items.name: electrolysis
items.description: A permanent hair removal technique that destroys follicles one at a time with a hair-thin needle inserted into the base of the follicle.

items.name: electrolyte
items.description: Minerals in the body that are electrically charged and play an important role in body processes, such as regulating fluid levels in the body. Examples include calcium and sodium.

items.name: electromyography
items.description: A test that checks the health of muscles and the nerves that control them.

items.name: electron-beam computed tomography
items.description: A high-speed imaging technology use to evaluate the heart and measure calcium deposits in arteries. Sometimes referred to as EBCT.

items.name: electrophysiologic testing
items.description: A procedure used to provoke known or suspected arrhythmias.

items.name: elimination diets
items.description: A way of diagnosing food allergies in which suspected foods are removed from the diet one at a time until the food causing a problem is found.

items.name: ellagic acid
items.description: A chemical found in certain plants, such as raspberries and strawberries, that might help protect against cancer.

items.name: embolic stroke
items.description: A type of stroke that occurs when a blood clot that has formed elsewhere in the body breaks off and travels through the bloodstream until it blocks an artery that normally supplies blood to the brain.

items.name: embolism
items.description: Blockage of a blood vessel by a clot (an embolus) that has traveled from another part of the body.

items.name: embolus
items.description: A blood clot or particle that forms in one part of the body then moves through the bloodstream and lodges in a blood vessel elsewhere, blocking blood flow.

items.name: emetic
items.description: Any drug or other substance used to cause vomiting.

items.name: EMG
items.description: Abbreviation for electromyography—a test that checks the health of muscles and the nerves that control them.

items.name: emission
items.description: The discharge or release of a substance, usually a fluid.

items.name: emmenagogue
items.description: Herbs that stimulate menstrual blood flow.

items.name: enamel
items.description: The hard outside layer of tooth material.

items.name: encephalitis
items.description: A severe and sometimes deadly inflammation of the brain that can be caused by a number of different viruses.

items.name: encoding
items.description: A multistage process by which sensation, perception, or thought is transformed into neural representations that can be stored in memory.

items.name: endarterectomy
items.description: Surgical removal of plaque or blood clots in an artery.

items.name: endemic
items.description: Continually present among people in a geographic region.

items.name: endocarditis
items.description: An inflammation of the heart lining or valves, usually caused by bacterial infection.

items.name: endocardium
items.description: The inner layer of the wall of the heart.

items.name: endogenous opioids
items.description: Painkilling substances made by the body.

items.name: endometrium
items.description: The lining of the uterus.

items.name: endorphins
items.description: Substances in the body that reduce pain and create a feeling of well-being.

items.name: endoscope
items.description: A thin, flexible tube equipped with a light and camera that is used to see inside an organ or body cavity.

items.name: endoscopy
items.description: Inserting a flexible tube equipped with a light and camera into the body to see inside a body cavity or organ.

items.name: endothelins
items.description: Proteins that cause blood vessels to narrow and blood pressure to rise.

items.name: endothelium-derived relaxing factor
items.description: Chemicals in the body that cause blood vessels to expand or relax, lowering blood pressure. Often referred to as EDRF.

items.name: end-stage renal disease
items.description: Complete, or nearly complete, kidney failure. Dialysis or a transplant is needed for survival.

items.name: enkephalin
items.description: A chemical produced in the brain that reduces pain.

items.name: enteric nervous system
items.description: Part of the nervous system that controls the gastrointestinal system.

items.name: enteropathic
items.description: Disease affecting the intestinal tract.

items.name: enthesis
items.description: A place where a ligament, tendon, or muscle attaches to bone.

items.name: entropion
items.description: An eyelid, usually the lower lid, which folds inward so that the eyelashes rub against and irritate the surface of the eye.

items.name: enzyme
items.description: A substance that speeds up another chemical reaction. For example, digestive enzymes help speed up the digestion of food.

items.name: eosinophils
items.description: White blood cells that play an important role in allergic reactions.

items.name: epicardium
items.description: The outer layer of the wall of the heart.

items.name: epicondylitis
items.description: Pain and swelling in the tendons in the elbow, usually because of overuse.

items.name: epidemic
items.description: The occurrence of more cases of disease than expected within a population in a geographic area over a set period of time.

items.name: epidemiological study
items.description: An investigation of the links between certain behaviors or risk factors and the occurrence of disease or good health in a population.

items.name: epidermis
items.description: The outermost layer of skin.

items.name: epidural space
items.description: The space between the spinal cord and the bones of the spinal column where painkillers are injected.

items.name: epinephrine
items.description: A chemical that narrows blood vessels, increases heart rate, and helps trigger the fight-or-flight response to danger. Also called adrenaline.

items.name: EpiPen
items.description: A device used to inject a dose of medication (epinephrine) when a severe allergic reaction occurs.

items.name: epithelial cells
items.description: Cells which line organs and structures in the body, protecting or enclosing them.

items.name: epithelium
items.description: A layer of cells which lines organs and structures in the body, protecting or enclosing them.

items.name: erectile dysfunction
items.description: The inability to get or maintain an erection sufficient for intercourse. Sometimes referred to as ED.

items.name: erector spinae
items.description: A group of muscles and tendons in the back.

items.name: ergonomics
items.description: Designing and arranging work objects so that the user is comfortable, efficient, and less likely to be injured.

items.name: ergots
items.description: Substances derived from or made from a fungus; often used to treat headache.

items.name: eructation
items.description: The act of bringing up air from the stomach through the mouth with a characteristic sound. Commonly known as belching.

items.name: erythema
items.description: Redness of the skin because of widening of capillaries just below the surface of the skin.

items.name: erythema nodosum
items.description: Painful, red lumps beneath the skin; associated with Crohn's disease.

items.name: erythrocyte sedimentation rate
items.description: A test involving red blood cells; used to check for different infections, inflammations, and cancers.

items.name: erythropoietin
items.description: A hormone that controls red blood cell production.

items.name: esophageal manometry
items.description: A test to measure the pressure inside the lower part of the esophagus.

items.name: esophagitis
items.description: Irritation and swelling of the esophagus.

items.name: esophagus
items.description: The tube that carries food and liquids from the mouth to the stomach.

items.name: essential fats
items.description: Two fatty acids, omega-3 and omega-6, that the body needs for good health but can’t make so they must come from foods and supplements.

items.name: essential hypertension
items.description: High blood pressure with no known cause; also called primary hypertension.

items.name: esterified estrogens
items.description: Artificially made hormones used to manage menopausal symptoms.

items.name: esthetician
items.description: A person who specializes in non-medical skin care and beauty treatments.

items.name: estradiol
items.description: The primary form of the sex hormone estrogen produced by women.

items.name: estrogen
items.description: The main sex hormone in women.

items.name: estrogen receptor
items.description: A site on the surface of some cells to which estrogen molecules attach.

items.name: estrogen-replacement therapy
items.description: Use of medications containing the sex hormone estrogen by women to replace naturally-occurring estrogen lost during menopause.

items.name: etidronate
items.description: A medication used to treat bone loss due to Paget's disease.

items.name: eustachian tube
items.description: A tube connecting the middle ear and the back of the nose that lets air into the middle ear.

items.name: euthyroid
items.description: Having a thyroid gland that works properly.

items.name: excitatory neurotransmitter
items.description: A chemical that forwards a message from one neuron to another.

items.name: excitotoxin
items.description: A brain chemical that damages neurons.

items.name: executive functions
items.description: The component of thinking that organizes, plans, decides, and inhibits inappropriate impulses.

items.name: exercise
items.description: A structured program of physical activity that helps an individual become physically fit.

items.name: exercise stress test
items.description: The use of a treadmill, stationary bicycle, or other exercise machine while hooked up to heart-monitoring equipment. The test is used to determine if the heart's blood supply is sufficient and if the rhythm remains normal when the heart is stressed.

items.name: exophthalmos
items.description: A protrusion or bulging of the eye that occurs with Graves’ eye disease. Tissues behind the eye swell, forcing the eyeball forward. Also called proptosis.

items.name: exostosis
items.description: Abnormal bony growths in the ear caused by swimming regularly in cold water. Sometimes called surfer's ear.

items.name: experience sampling
items.description: A research technique for learning about people’s activity patterns and psychological processes that involves paging them at random times to obtain brief reports.

items.name: expression hopping
items.description: A common phenomenon whereby people jump to a different expression of addiction. For example, people with heroin addiction might transition to alcohol addiction. Hopping is especially common during the recovery process.

items.name: expression of addiction
items.description: The specific way in which a person manifests addiction, for example, through the use of cocaine, or compulsive gambling.

items.name: extend
items.description: To straighten out a joint (for example, extending the arms overhead).

items.name: external otitis
items.description: An infection or irritation of the outer ear, ear canal, or both. Also called swimmer’s ear.

items.name: extracapsular cataract surgery
items.description: A surgical technique to remove a cataract from the eye.

items.name: extract
items.description: A product made from substances that are drawn out of a plant or herb.

items.name: extraocular muscles
items.description: Six paired muscles that direct the eyes’ circular, side-to-side, and up-and-down movements.

items.name: extrinsic factor
items.description: An outside factor that has an effect on a person’s environment or well-being.

items.name: facet joints
items.description: Paired joints that link a vertebra to its neighboring vertebrae. They allow the spine to move as a unit.

items.name: facet rhizotomy
items.description: Surgical destruction of certain nerves and nerve roots to relieve pain.

items.name: false negative
items.description: Test results that show that a disease or substance isn’t present, even though it is.

items.name: familial combined hyperlipidemia
items.description: An inherited disorder in which the liver overproduces very low-density lipoprotein, causing high levels of cholesterol or triglycerides, or both.

items.name: familial hypercholesterolemia
items.description: An inherited disorder in which the liver cannot properly remove low-density lipoprotein particles from the blood, causing a very high cholesterol level.

items.name: fasting lipid profile
items.description: A laboratory test to determine the relative levels of high-density lipoprotein, low-density lipoprotein, and total cholesterol in the blood. Also referred to as a lipoprotein analysis, full lipid profile, or cholesterol profile.

items.name: fasting plasma glucose test
items.description: A blood test that determines the amount of sugar (glucose) in the blood after an overnight fast of at least eight hours.

items.name: fast-twitch fiber
items.description: One of two main types of skeletal muscle fibers. Fast-twitch fibers are recruited most heavily when bursts of power are needed, as in sprinting. See also slow-twitch fiber.

items.name: fat
items.description: One of the three major nutrients, along with carbohydrates and proteins.

items.name: fatigue
items.description: A lack of energy. A decrease over time in the ability to perform a physical or mental task.

items.name: fatty acids
items.description: Components of fats that can be used for energy by cells.

items.name: fatty streak
items.description: The first stage of atherosclerosis, a build-up of fatty materials in the wall of a blood vessel.

items.name: febrile
items.description: Feverish; having a high body temperature.

items.name: fecal impaction
items.description: A mass of dry, hard stool that gets lodged in the rectum.

items.name: fecal occult blood test
items.description: A test that checks for colorectal cancer by detecting blood in the stool.

items.name: femur
items.description: Thigh bone.

items.name: ferritin
items.description: A protein that captures and stores iron.

items.name: fetal alcohol syndrome
items.description: A collection of birth defects resulting from exposure of the fetus to alcohol during pregnancy.

items.name: fiber
items.description: A substance found in plant foods that the body can’t digest.

items.name: fibrillation
items.description: Rapid and uncoordinated contractions of heart muscle fibers. When this occurs, the heart can't properly contract or pump blood.

items.name: fibrin
items.description: A stringy protein that is the primary component of a blood clot.

items.name: fibrinogen
items.description: A protein that helps stop bleeding by aiding in forming blood clots.

items.name: fibroadenoma
items.description: A tumor that is not cancer; usually found in the breast.

items.name: fibroblast
items.description: A cell that helps form the collagen and elastic fibers of connective tissue.

items.name: fibroid
items.description: A tumor that is not cancer, which is found in the uterus.

items.name: fibromyalgia
items.description: A condition causing pain and tender spots throughout the body.

items.name: fibrous plaque
items.description: A buildup of fat on the inside of a blood vessel that interferes with blood flow.

items.name: fibula
items.description: The calf bone.

items.name: filtering procedure
items.description: A procedure to treat glaucoma in which a surgeon creates a drainage hole in the eye to relieve pressure.

items.name: finasteride
items.description: A medication for treating benign prostatic hyperplasia (enlargement of the prostate gland).

items.name: fixed joint
items.description: An area where two bones meet that is fixed, or doesn’t move.

items.name: flaccid
items.description: Soft, not erect.

items.name: flare
items.description: Reappearance or worsening of symptoms.

items.name: flat feet
items.description: A condition in which the arch is flat all the time or flattens when bearing weight.

items.name: flatulence
items.description: Excess gas in the stomach or intestines that is expelled from the anus.

items.name: flatus
items.description: Gas expelled through the anus.

items.name: flavonoids
items.description: Chemicals found in fruits, vegetables, wine, and tea that may protect cells from damage and have health benefits.

items.name: flex
items.description: Bend a joint (for example, flexing the knees).

items.name: flexibility
items.description: A component of physical fitness that refers to the range of motion available at a joint.

items.name: flight-or-fight response
items.description: Changes that occur in the body, such as rapid breathing and heartbeat, when a person is confronted with a perceived physical or emotional threat. Also called the stress response.

items.name: floaters
items.description: Tiny spots or lines that appear in a person’s field of vision when the jelly-like fluid of the eye breaks down with age. They are usually harmless, but can signal serious eye problems.

items.name: flow
items.description: A term coined by positive psychology pioneer Mihaly Csikszentmihalyi to describe an effortless, active state of being during which one loses awareness of time, self, and distractions. Flow hinges on balancing the size of a challenge and the level of skill a person brings to it.

items.name: fluorescein angiography
items.description: A test that uses special dye and a camera to examine blood flow in the retina.

items.name: fluoride
items.description: A mineral that protects teeth from decay and cavities.

items.name: fluoroscopy
items.description: A test that gives moving images of the inside of the body; could be likened to an x-ray movie.

items.name: foam cells
items.description: Lipid-laden cells, named for their foamy appearance under the microscope. As foam cells build up on the inside of blood vessel walls, they form a plaque that can block blood flow.

items.name: focal neuropathy
items.description: Damage to a specific nerve, causing pain or numbness.

items.name: focus words
items.description: Peaceful, relaxing words or phrases used during stress relief exercises.

items.name: follicle
items.description: A group of cells that form a small sac.

items.name: follicle-stimulating hormone
items.description: A hormone released by the pituitary gland that stimulates the production of eggs in women and sperm in men.

items.name: follicular unit
items.description: A small bundle that includes one to four follicles, oil glands, a tiny muscle, and other tissue.

items.name: follicular unit transplantation
items.description: Transplantation of follicular units, which mimic natural hair growth.

items.name: folliculitis
items.description: An inflammation of the hair follicle.

items.name: food allergies
items.description: Sensitivities to certain foods that can cause symptoms ranging from the mild (like hives) to the life threatening (such as anaphylaxis).

items.name: forehead lift
items.description: Cosmetic surgery to minimize creases on the forehead and between the eyebrows, and to lift sagging eyebrows.

items.name: fovea
items.description: A small dimple in the middle of the retina that provides sharp central vision.

items.name: fracture
items.description: A break in a bone.

items.name: FRAX tool
items.description: An algorithm for estimating the probability of breaking a bone because of low bone mass over a period of 10 years.

items.name: free fragment
items.description: Part of a disk in the back that has broken off from the main portion of the disk.

items.name: free radical
items.description: An unstable molecule in the body that plays a role in aging and can damage tissue; antioxidants help prevent free radical damage.

items.name: frequency
items.description: The pitch of a sound; measured by the speed at which sound waves vibrate.

items.name: frequency range
items.description: How much amplification a hearing aid produces in both high and low frequencies.

items.name: frequency response
items.description: The amplification that a hearing aid produces across different sound frequencies.

items.name: frontal lobe
items.description: Part of the brain that plays a role in determining consequences and choosing behaviors.

items.name: frontotemporal lobar degeneration
items.description: A brain disorder that can cause dementia, aphasia, neurotic behavior, and gradual changes in personality and emotional control.

items.name: frozen shoulder
items.description: Inflammation of various tissues of the shoulder, along with growth of abnormal bands of tissue that cause the shoulder to become so stiff that movement is severely limited.

items.name: fructose
items.description: A simple sugar found in corn syrup, honey, and many sweet fruits.

items.name: FSH
items.description: Abbreviation for follicle-stimulating hormone, a hormone released by the pituitary gland that stimulates the production of eggs in women and sperm in men.

items.name: functional gastrointestinal disorders
items.description: Gut problems that aren’t caused by an infection or structural problem with the gastrointestinal system.

items.name: functional incontinence
items.description: Recognition of the need to urinate but being unable to get to the bathroom in time due to mental or physical problems, such as limited mobility.

items.name: fundoplication
items.description: Surgery that restructures the stomach to prevent acid reflux.

items.name: fundus photography
items.description: Imaging test that provides multi-dimensional pictures of the back of the eyeball.

items.name: fungus
items.description: Organisms and microorganisms, such as yeasts and molds, that can live as a parasite on plants and animals.

items.name: gain
items.description: A hearing aid’s power, measured in the number of decibels that it can add to sound.

items.name: gait cycle
items.description: The cycle that the feet and legs make when walking, beginning when one heel hits the ground and ending when the same heel hits the ground again.

items.name: galactogogue
items.description: A substance that promotes breast milk production.

items.name: gamma-aminobutyric acid
items.description: A chemical messenger in the brain that may help decrease anxiety and promote slow-wave sleep. Often referred to as GABA.

items.name: ganglion
items.description: An abnormal but harmless mass of tissue, usually nerve cells.

items.name: ganglion cyst
items.description: A harmless sac of fluid on top of a joint or tendon, usually on the wrist or back of the hand.

items.name: gangrene
items.description: Death of tissue in part of the body because blood has stopped flowing there.

items.name: gastric
items.description: Relating to the stomach.

items.name: gastritis
items.description: Inflammation of the lining of the stomach.

items.name: gastroesophageal reflux disease
items.description: A condition in which food and acid flow back into the esophagus from the stomach, causing heartburn.

items.name: gastrointestinal
items.description: Relating to all or some of the organs of the digestive tract, from the mouth to the anus.

items.name: gastrointestinal tract
items.description: The digestive tract.

items.name: gene
items.description: Structures on chromosomes that are passed from parent to child. The basic unit of material that passes traits from parent to child.

items.name: gene therapy
items.description: Correction of a genetic defect by replacing an abnormal gene with a normal gene.

items.name: generic drug
items.description: A copy of a brand-name drug whose patent has expired. These drugs are less expensive than brand-name drugs.

items.name: genetic
items.description: Referring to inherited characteristics or genes.

items.name: genistein
items.description: An antioxidant chemical found in certain plants, like soybeans.

items.name: GERD
items.description: Abbreviation for gastroesophageal reflux disease, a condition in which food and acid flow back into the esophagus from the stomach, causing heartburn.

items.name: geriatric care manager
items.description: A trained medical professional who helps families who are caring for older adults.

items.name: geriatrician
items.description: A physician who specializes in the care of older patients.

items.name: gestational diabetes mellitus
items.description: A form of diabetes that appears during pregnancy.

items.name: GFR
items.description: Abbreviation for glomerular filtration rate, the rate at which the kidneys filter excess water and other wastes. A test by the same name is used to determine how well the kidneys are functioning.

items.name: giant cell arteritis
items.description: Inflammation and damage to blood vessels that supply the head and neck.

items.name: gingiva
items.description: Another term for gums : a form of oral tissue that covers the roots of teeth and surrounding bone.

items.name: gingivitis
items.description: Inflammation of the gums.

items.name: gland
items.description: Any organ or tissue that secretes fluids, such as hormones, for use elsewhere in the body or as waste.

items.name: glans penis
items.description: The head of the penis.

items.name: glaucoma
items.description: A condition in which the pressure inside the eye is too high, causing eye damage.

items.name: Gleason score
items.description: In men with prostate cancer, the Gleason score provides a rough estimate of how fast the cancer is growing.

items.name: glenohumeral joint
items.description: A shoulder joint that connects the ball of the humerus to the glenoid.

items.name: glenoid
items.description: The socket of the scapula that connects to the humerus at the shoulder.

items.name: glomerular filtration rate
items.description: The rate at which the kidneys filter excess water and other wastes. A test by the same name is used to determine how well the kidneys are functioning.

items.name: glomeruli
items.description: Tiny clusters of capillaries in the kidneys that filter waste products from the blood.

items.name: glucagon
items.description: A hormone produced in the pancreas that raises blood sugar levels.

items.name: glucocorticoids
items.description: Steroid hormones released by the adrenal gland when there seems to be a threat, and the stress response is triggered.

items.name: glucose
items.description: A simple sugar that is the body’s main source of energy.

items.name: glucose intolerance
items.description: Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal, but not yet high enough for a diagnosis of diabetes.

items.name: glutamate
items.description: A chemical messenger in the brain that may play a role in mood disorders and schizophrenia.

items.name: glutamic acid decarboxylase
items.description: A protein found in beta cells, the cells that create insulin.

items.name: glycemic index
items.description: A ranking of foods according to how quickly and how much they raise blood sugar.

items.name: glycemic load
items.description: A ranking of how much a typical serving of a particular food will raise blood sugar.

items.name: glycogen
items.description: The body’s fuel reserves. This substance, stored primarily in the liver and muscles, is later converted into glucose to provide cells with energy.

items.name: glycosylated hemoglobin
items.description: The product formed by the attachment of glucose (blood sugar) to hemoglobin (the oxygen-carrying protein in red blood cells). Usually referred to as hemoglobin A1c, or HbA1c.

items.name: GnRH
items.description: Abbreviation for gonadotropin-releasing hormone, a hormone responsible for the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone from the pituitary gland.

items.name: GnRH antagonists
items.description: Drugs used to treat prostate cancer by blocking the release of luteinizing hormone that do not cause a temporary surge in testosterone.

items.name: goblet cells
items.description: Cells that produce mucus that line the gastrointestinal tract and lungs.

items.name: goiter
items.description: An enlarged thyroid gland that creates a lump in the neck.

items.name: gonadotropin-releasing hormone
items.description: A hormone responsible for the release of follicle-stimulating hormone and luteinizing hormone from the pituitary gland.

items.name: gonioscopy
items.description: A test used to detect glaucoma that examines the area where fluid drains out of the eye.

items.name: gout
items.description: A form of arthritis that occurs when uric acid builds up in the joints; The big toe, knee, and ankle joints are most often affected.

items.name: graft
items.description: Transplanting tissue from one part of the body to another.

items.name: gram
items.description: A metric unit of weight equivalent to one-thousandth of a kilogram.

items.name: Graves’ disease
items.description: An autoimmune disease that causes the thyroid gland to produce too much thyroid hormone. It is usually accompanied by an enlarged thyroid gland and swollen, bulging, red eyes that appear to stare, as well as occasional double vision and vision loss.

items.name: greenstick fracture
items.description: A fracture in a young, soft bone in which the bone bends and breaks only on the outer edge of the bend.

items.name: grief
items.description: A broad range of reactions to bereavement, including sadness, tears, shock, confusion, and anger, among others.

items.name: growth factor
items.description: A substance produced by the body to stimulate tissue growth.

items.name: G spot
items.description: The area of sexually sensitive tissue located on the roof of the vagina just inside the opening. Also known as the Grafenberg spot.

items.name: guardianship
items.description: A legal process of appointing a person to make decisions about important matters (such as health and finances) for someone who is unfit to make those decisions on his or her own.

items.name: gullet
items.description: The esophagus.

items.name: gum disease
items.description: Diseases including gingivitis and periodontitis that attack the gum tissue and the structures supporting the teeth. Also called periodontal disease.

items.name: gums
items.description: A form of oral tissue that covers the roots of teeth and surrounding bone. Also called the gingiva.

items.name: hair bulb
items.description: The root of the hair shaft.

items.name: hair cells
items.description: Cells in the ear that transmit sound messages to the brain and play a vital role in hearing.

items.name: hair shaft
items.description: The portion of hair that extends beyond the surface of the skin. It contains three layers : the cuticle, cortex, and medulla (not always present).

items.name: hallucination
items.description: A perception of something that is not really there.

items.name: hammertoe
items.description: A sometimes painful condition in which the toe curls up and under (resembling a hammer).

items.name: happiness
items.description: Feelings of contentment or joy; the overall experience of pleasure and meaning in life.

items.name: happiness set-point
items.description: An individual's baseline level of happiness, determined largely by genetics, around which moods fluctuate. After reacting to positive or negative life changes, people tend to return to their happiness set-points.

items.name: harm reduction therapy
items.description: A treatment strategy aimed at minimizing the harm associated with an object of addiction. This strategic approach helps people learn how to limit the degree to which they use their object of addiction, or limit the risks associated with their use, but they do not necessarily stop altogether.

items.name: Hashimoto's thyroiditis
items.description: A disease in which the body’s immune system prevents the thyroid gland from producing enough thyroid hormone.

items.name: hay fever
items.description: A commonly used term for allergic rhinitis—seasonal or year-round allergic condition marked by sneezing, runny nose, and congestion. The most common type of allergy, it is caused by an IgE-mediated immune response to inhaled airborne allergens.

items.name: HbA1c
items.description: Abbreviation for hemoglobin A1c, the product formed by the attachment of glucose (blood sugar) to hemoglobin (a protein in red blood cells). A test for HbA1c is a useful measure of blood sugar control.

items.name: HDL
items.description: Abbreviation for high-density lipoprotein, the so-called good cholesterol. This lipoprotein (a substance made up of fats and protein) is believed to remove cholesterol from the arteries.

items.name: health care proxy
items.description: A legal form allowing a person to appoint someone else to make their medical decisions. Also known as a durable power of attorney for health care.

items.name: hearing aid
items.description: An electronic device worn in or behind the ear by people with hearing problems that makes sounds louder.

items.name: heart attack
items.description: The common term for a myocardial infarction. It refers to the damage that occurs when blood flow to part of the heart is blocked or drastically restricted. The blockage usually stems from the rupture of an atherosclerotic plaque.

items.name: heart block
items.description: The difficulty or inability of the electrical signal that triggers a heart contraction to pass through the atrioventricular node.

items.name: heart failure
items.description: The inability of the heart to pump enough blood to meet the needs of the body's organs.

items.name: heart murmur
items.description: An extra or unusual sound heard during the heartbeat. A murmur may or may not be a sign of a problem in the heart.

items.name: heart rate
items.description: The number of times the heart contracts in a minute, normally 60–100 times.

items.name: heartburn
items.description: A burning pain in the chest or throat, caused when stomach acid backs up into the esophagus.

items.name: Heberden’s nodes
items.description: Bony bumps found on the finger joints in some people with osteoarthritis.

items.name: hedonic
items.description: Devoted to pleasure.

items.name: hedonic treadmill
items.description: The human tendency to adapt to new circumstances and eventually consider them to be normal, so the emotional effects (negative or positive) generated by a change fade over time.

items.name: heel spur
items.description: An abnormal growth of bone or calcium on the heel bone.

items.name: Helicobacter pylori
items.description: Bacteria that damages the lining the stomach. It is to blame for most ulcers and stomach inflammation. Often called H. pylori.

items.name: helper T cells
items.description: Cells that help fight disease by activating and directing other immune system cells.

items.name: hematemesis
items.description: The vomiting of bright red blood, indicating bleeding in the upper digestive tract.

items.name: hematoma
items.description: Blood that leaks out of blood vessels and collects in the body.

items.name: hematuria
items.description: Blood in the urine.

items.name: hemianopia
items.description: Poor vision or blindness in half of the visual field, affecting one or both eyes.

items.name: hemiparesis
items.description: Muscle weakness on one side of the body.

items.name: hemiplegia
items.description: Paralysis on one side of the body.

items.name: hemochromatosis
items.description: A genetic condition in which the body absorbs and stores too much iron.

items.name: hemodialysis
items.description: The use of a machine to remove wastes and impurities from the blood when the kidneys are not working properly.

items.name: hemoglobin
items.description: The oxygen-carrying substance that gives red blood cells their color.

items.name: hemoptysis
items.description: Coughing up or spitting up blood from the lungs.

items.name: hemorrhage
items.description: Bleeding from a damaged blood vessel.

items.name: hemorrhagic stroke
items.description: A type of stroke that occurs when a blood vessel leaks or bursts inside the brain, cutting off the supply of oxygen and nutrition to that part of the brain.

items.name: HEPA filter
items.description: Abbreviation for high-efficiency particulate air, a type of highly efficient air filter.

items.name: heparin
items.description: A drug that prevents blood from clotting.

items.name: herd immunity
items.description: Protection occurring when so many people in a region are immune to an infectious disease that it can’t spread to others.

items.name: herniated disk
items.description: When part of a spinal disk bulges out of a tear or weak spot in the disk’s tough outer shell. Also known as prolapsed disk.

items.name: herpes zoster
items.description: A painful blistering skin rash caused by the chicken pox virus; also known as shingles.

items.name: hertz
items.description: The measurement of a sound’s frequency.

items.name: hiatal hernia
items.description: When part of the stomach pushes upward into the chest through an abnormal opening in the diaphragm.

items.name: high blood pressure
items.description: When blood flowing through arteries pushes on artery walls with abnormally high force over a sustained period of time. Also called hypertension.

items.name: high-density lipoprotein
items.description: So-called good cholesterol. This lipoprotein (a substance made of fat and protein) removes cholesterol from arteries.

items.name: high-intensity focused ultrasound
items.description: A treatment that destroys tumors with heat generated by ultrasound energy.

items.name: hippocampus
items.description: Part of the brain that plays an important role in processing long-term memories.

items.name: hirsutism
items.description: Excessive facial or body hair in women.

items.name: histamine
items.description: A substance released by the immune system when it is exposed to an allergen. Histamines cause many allergy symptoms.

items.name: HIV
items.description: Abbreviation for human immunodeficiency virus, the virus that leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). HIV damages immune cells so that they are no longer able to fight off other infections.

items.name: hives
items.description: An itchy rash of usually short duration. Also known as urticaria.

items.name: HLA
items.description: Abbreviation for human leukocyte antigen, a protein found on the surface of white blood cells that helps the body recognize and fight foreign substances.

items.name: Holter monitor
items.description: A small machine worn for a day or more to continuously record the heart’s electrical activity. Holter monitors are used to help diagnose heart rhythm problems.

items.name: homeostasis
items.description: The body’s ability to keep blood pressure, temperature, water levels, oxygen levels, and more set at the right levels for cells to survive.

items.name: homocysteine
items.description: An amino acid formed as part of the normal breakdown of protein.

items.name: homocystinuria
items.description: A rare genetic disease that causes blood levels of homocysteine to rise too high.

items.name: hormone therapy
items.description: Use of medications to boost levels of hormones that decrease with age.

items.name: hormones
items.description: Powerful chemicals that affect many processes in the body, including sexual function, mood, and growth.

items.name: host
items.description: A person or other living organism that can be infected by a virus or other pathogen under natural conditions.

items.name: hot flash
items.description: A sudden, intense, hot feeling in the face or upper part of the body, along with rapid heartbeat, sweating, and flushing. A symptom of menopause.

items.name: HPA
items.description: Abbreviation for hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis, a system that controls many hormonal activities in the body, including the stress response.

items.name: human immunodeficiency virus
items.description: Usually abbreviated as HIV, the virus that leads to acquired immunodeficiency syndrome (AIDS). HIV damages immune cells so that they are no longer able to fight off other infections.

items.name: human leukocyte antigen
items.description: A protein found on the surface of white blood cells that helps the body recognize and fight foreign substances.

items.name: humectant
items.description: An agent used in moisturizers; binds water to the skin to promote hydration.

items.name: humoral immunity
items.description: Immunity from infection and disease that comes from the release of antibodies in the blood.

items.name: Huntington's disease
items.description: An inherited disorder characterized by involuntary jerky movements and dementia.

items.name: hyaluronic acid
items.description: A hydrating sugar secreted by cells.

items.name: hydrogen breath test
items.description: A test used to diagnose gastrointestinal problems; it measures the amount of hydrogen in the breath, which rise when food isn’t being absorbed properly.

items.name: hydrogenation
items.description: The addition of hydrogen to a compound. Hydrogenation is used to solidify liquid vegetable oils. The process creates trans fats, which are harmful to the heart and blood vessels.

items.name: hydroxyapatite
items.description: A hard substance that is a major component of bones and teeth.

items.name: hygiene hypothesis
items.description: The theory that modern cleanliness means children are not exposed to as many germs at an early age, which results in a more allergies.

items.name: hyperaldosteronism
items.description: Overproduction of the hormone aldosterone, which causes the kidneys to retain sodium and water, often leading to high blood pressure.

items.name: hyperalgesia
items.description: An increased sensitivity to pain.

items.name: hypercholesterolemia
items.description: High levels of cholesterol in the blood.

items.name: hyperglycemia
items.description: An abnormally high amount of sugar in the blood.

items.name: hyperinsulinemia
items.description: High levels of insulin in the bloodstream.

items.name: hyperlipidemia
items.description: High levels of blood lipids (fats and waxes such as cholesterol).

items.name: hyperopia
items.description: Difficulty seeing objects that are nearby; farsightedness.

items.name: hyperparathyroidism
items.description: Overproduction by the thyroid glands of parathyroid hormone.

items.name: hyperplasia
items.description: Increased production of cells in a normal tissue or organ; may be harmless or a sign of precancerous changes.

items.name: hyperplastic polyp
items.description: Noncancerous growths commonly found in the colon and rectum.

items.name: hypertension
items.description: The medical term for high blood pressure. Hypertension is a major risk factor for stroke, especially hemorrhagic and lacunar strokes, because it puts excess stress on the walls of blood vessels and damages their delicate inner lining.

items.name: hypertensive cerebellar hemorrhage
items.description: A stroke in which there is bleeding in the cerebellum because high blood pressure has weakened arteries in the brain.

items.name: hypertensive intracerebral hemorrhage
items.description: A stroke in which high blood pressure causes a blood vessel deep in the brain to rupture.

items.name: hyperthyroidism
items.description: A condition in which the thyroid gland makes too much thyroid hormone.

items.name: hypertriglyceridemia
items.description: High levels of triglycerides in the blood. A normal triglyceride level is less than 150 mg/dL.

items.name: hyperuricemia
items.description: Abnormally high levels of uric acid in the blood.

items.name: hypnagogic hallucinations
items.description: Vivid dream-like sounds or images that occur while on the verge of falling asleep.

items.name: hypnogram
items.description: A diagram that summarizes the stages of sleep recorded in a sleep laboratory.

items.name: hypnotic
items.description: An agent that promotes and aids sleep.

items.name: hypoglycemia
items.description: A condition in which blood sugar drops to an abnormally low level.

items.name: hypogonadism
items.description: Extremely low levels of testosterone in circulation.

items.name: hypomania
items.description: A mild form of mania, in which a person has lots of energy, talks faster than normal, has racing thoughts, and elevated mood.

items.name: hypopnea
items.description: Breathing that is more shallow and slow than normal.

items.name: hypotension
items.description: The medical term for low blood pressure.

items.name: hypothalamic-pituitary-adrenal axis
items.description: A system that controls many hormonal activities in the body, including the stress response. Often called the HPA axis.

items.name: hypothalamus
items.description: A small area in the brain that produces hormones that control body temperature, hunger, moods, the stress response, and other key functions.

items.name: hypothyroidism
items.description: A disease in which the thyroid gland does not make enough thyroid hormone.

items.name: hypoxia
items.description: When all or part of the body doesn’t get enough oxygen.

items.name: hysterectomy
items.description: An operation to remove a woman’s uterus.

items.name: iatrogenic
items.description: Complications or poor effects caused by medical treatment.

items.name: IBD
items.description: Abbreviation for inflammatory bowel disease, a general term for two disorders—ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease—that cause the intestines to become swollen and inflamed.

items.name: ICD
items.description: Abbreviation for implantable cardioverter defibrillator, a device implanted in the chest and connected to the heart that delivers a shock to stop a potentially deadly rhythm and restore a normal (sinus) rhythm.

items.name: ice pick headache
items.description: Stabbing, very intense headaches that come on suddenly and are very brief.

items.name: idiopathic
items.description: A condition or disease of unknown origin.

items.name: IgE
items.description: Abbreviation for immunoglobulin E, the substance responsible for most allergic reactions.

items.name: ileum
items.description: The final section of the small intestine.

items.name: iliopsoas muscles
items.description: Two muscles, running from the end of the spine to the thighbone, that are responsible for lifting the knee.

items.name: immediate hypersensitivity
items.description: A category of allergic reaction, triggered by specific allergens and involving IgE. The majority of allergic reactions to pollens, pets, dust, mold, food, and insect venom are of this type.

items.name: immobilize
items.description: To restrict the movement of a limb or other part of the body to help in healing.

items.name: immunity
items.description: The body’s ability to resist infection and disease.

items.name: immunization
items.description: Injection of harmless bacteria or viruses to spur the body to produce antibodies so it can resist a particular disease.

items.name: immunoglobulin
items.description: Substances made by the immune system that attack foreign substances. Also known as antibodies.

items.name: immunoglobulin E
items.description: The substance responsible for most allergic reactions.

items.name: immunologically privileged site
items.description: A part of the body—such as the eye or ovaries—where the immune system isn’t able to function because it may damage the tissue there.

items.name: immunosuppressant drug
items.description: Medication that stifles the body's immune response; often given after an organ transplant to prevent rejection of the new organ.

items.name: immunotherapy
items.description: Treating disease by enhancing or suppressing the body’s immune system.

items.name: impacted
items.description: Something firmly fixed into place, such as a wisdom tooth.

items.name: impaction
items.description: A mass of hardened feces blocking the rectum or colon.

items.name: impaired fasting glucose
items.description: Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with a fasting plasma glucose test.

items.name: impaired glucose tolerance
items.description: Blood sugar levels that are higher than normal but not yet diabetic. This term is used when the high blood sugar levels are found with an oral glucose tolerance test.

items.name: impedance hearing testing
items.description: A test that sends sound waves to the eardrum to determine if a problem in the middle ear is causing hearing loss.

items.name: implantable cardioverter defibrillator
items.description: A device implanted in the chest and connected to the heart that delivers a shock to stop a potentially deadly rhythm and restore a normal (sinus) rhythm.

items.name: impotence
items.description: The inability of the penis to become firm or to stay firm enough to have sexual intercourse.

items.name: in situ
items.description: Latin for in place.

items.name: inactivated vaccines
items.description: Vaccines containing microbes that have been killed, and, therefore, are unable to cause disease.

items.name: incision
items.description: A cut made into the skin or an organ during surgery.

items.name: incontinence
items.description: Involuntary passing of urine or feces.

items.name: incubation period
items.description: The time between when a person is exposed to an infection and when symptoms appear.

items.name: infarct
items.description: An area of dead tissue caused by insufficient blood supply.

items.name: infarction
items.description: The death of tissue due to a lack of blood.

items.name: infection
items.description: The growth of harmful organisms that can cause disease, such as bacteria, in the body.

items.name: infectious arthritis
items.description: Arthritis caused by harmful organisms such as bacteria.

items.name: inferior myocardial infarction
items.description: Heart attack involving the back part of the heart-muscle wall.

items.name: inferior vena cava
items.description: The large vein that carries blood from the lower half of the body to the heart.

items.name: infiltrating cancer
items.description: A cancer that has spread from where it first developed into surrounding tissue.

items.name: inflammation
items.description: The body’s reaction to injury or infection. It is characterized by swelling, heat, redness, and pain.

items.name: inflammatory bowel disease
items.description: A general term for two disorders, ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease, that cause the intestines to become swollen and inflamed. Often referred to as IBD.

items.name: infusion
items.description: The slow injection of a fluid into a vein or tissues.

items.name: ingrown toenail
items.description: A condition in which the side of a toenail pierces the skin, causing pain, swelling, and sometimes infection.

items.name: inhibitory neurochemical
items.description: A chemical that stops the transmission of a message from one nerve cell to another.

items.name: injectable fillers
items.description: Substances injected into the skin to fill in wrinkles or add plumpness to the lips.

items.name: injection
items.description: Inserting fluids, such as medications, into the body by means of a hollow needle and syringe.

items.name: innate immunity
items.description: The body’s basic defenses against disease or infection that are present from birth.

items.name: inner ear
items.description: The deepest part of the ear, consisting of the cochlea and the labyrinth.

items.name: inoperable
items.description: A condition that cannot be treated by surgery.

items.name: insomnia
items.description: The inability to fall asleep or remain asleep long enough to feel rested.

items.name: insulin
items.description: A hormone made by the pancreas that controls the amount of glucose (sugar) in the blood.

items.name: insulin resistance
items.description: A condition in which the body produces insulin but can’t use it properly. This leads to diabetes.

items.name: insulin-dependent diabetes
items.description: Now called type 1 diabetes. It occurs when the body doesn’t produce enough insulin to control blood sugar levels properly.

items.name: intense pulsed light
items.description: A device that emits broadband light to improve the look of the skin or remove unwanted hair.

items.name: intensity
items.description: In exercise, a measure of how hard the body is working. Cues like breathing, talking, and sweating help measure intensity through perceived exertion.

items.name: interferons
items.description: Proteins made by the body to protect against viruses, bacteria, and other harmful agents.

items.name: interleukins
items.description: A group of substances that act as messengers in the immune system.

items.name: intermediate-density lipoprotein
items.description: A type of lipoprotein. It consists of remnants of very-low-density lipoprotein (VLDL) that eventually turn into low-density lipoprotein (LDL).

items.name: intermittent claudication
items.description: Pain and cramping in the legs during exercise that is caused by narrowed or blocked arteries. Also known as peripheral artery disease of the legs.

items.name: international unit
items.description: An internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.

items.name: interpersonal therapy
items.description: Short-term talk therapy focused on identifying and addressing problems in current relationships and building social skills.

items.name: intervention
items.description: A planned, often group, meeting with a person with addiction, with the aim of overcoming denial and inducing the individual to seek treatment.

items.name: intervention study
items.description: A study that compares one group that receives a medication or other therapy (an intervention) and another group does not (controls).

items.name: intervertebral disk
items.description: One of the small, shock-absorbing cushions located between the vertebrae of the spine.

items.name: intervertebral foramen
items.description: The opening between vertebrae through which a spinal nerve exits the spinal column (plural : foramina).

items.name: intolerance
items.description: An adverse reaction that may have similar symptoms to an allergic reaction but does not engage the immune system, and thus is not an allergy.

items.name: intracerebral hemorrhage
items.description: A hemorrhagic stroke caused by the rupture of a blood vessel and subsequent bleeding into the brain tissue.

items.name: intraocular lens
items.description: A small artificial lens permanently fixed inside the eye to replace the natural lens during cataract surgery.

items.name: intrinsic sphincter deficiency
items.description: Inability of the urinary sphincter to close completely.

items.name: iodides
items.description: Salt compounds containing iodine that are used to control severe hyperthyroidism in special circumstances. They work by decreasing the thyroid gland’s production and secretion of thyroid hormone.

items.name: iris
items.description: The colored ring in front of the lens that controls the size of the pupil and how much light enters the eye.

items.name: irritants
items.description: Substances such as tobacco, wood smoke, perfumes, and others that cause allergy-like symptoms, although the response is not an allergic reaction.

items.name: ischemia
items.description: Inadequate blood supply to an organ or part of the body.

items.name: ischemic heart disease
items.description: The most common form of heart disease, in which narrowed or blocked coronary arteries have difficulty supplying sections of the heart muscle with the blood they need (ischemia).

items.name: ischemic stroke
items.description: A stroke caused by an interruption in the flow of blood to the brain; almost always caused by a blood clot blocking a blood vessel.

items.name: islets of Langerhans
items.description: Clusters of hormone-producing cells, including alpha and beta cells, that appear throughout the pancreas.

items.name: isolated systolic hypertension
items.description: A form of high blood pressure (hypertension) characterized by elevated systolic blood pressure and normal diastolic pressure.

items.name: isometric
items.description: An action in which a muscle generates force but does not contract or extend enough to move a joint, such as when pushing against an immovable object.

items.name: isotonic
items.description: An actions in which a muscle generates force by contracting or lengthening to move an attached joint through its range of motion, such as lifting a dumbbell from knee-height to shoulder-height.

items.name: IU
items.description: Commonly used abbreviation for international unit, an internationally accepted amount of a substance based on its biological activity or effect; used as a measurement for fat-soluble vitamins.

items.name: jejunum
items.description: The section of the small intestine between the duodenum and the ileum.

items.name: jet lag
items.description: A feeling of fatigue that occurs as the biological clock resets itself after traveling across time zones, usually by airplane.

items.name: joint
items.description: A junction in the body where bones are linked together.

items.name: julienne
items.description: To cut food into thin, matchstick strips.

items.name: Kegel
items.description: An exercise that helps prevent and treat incontinence by strengthening pelvic floor muscles.

items.name: keloid
items.description: An unusually hard or thick scar that forms after surgery or an injury.

items.name: keratectomy
items.description: A procedure in which a laser is used to correct vision problems by reshaping the cornea.

items.name: keratin
items.description: A protein and the major component of the cuticle and cortex layers of hair; the same protein is found in nails, feathers, claws, and hooves.

items.name: keratinocytes
items.description: Cells of the epidermis that produce a tough protein called keratin and form a soft, protective sheet for the body.

items.name: keratoconjunctivitis sicca
items.description: Persistent dryness of the eye.

items.name: keratoderma blennorrhagica
